statement.tex: \text{Differentiate the following function}\\ \text{with respect to x}\\ \quad f(x) = \cos x^3\cdot\sin^2 (x^5)

step.reason: \text{This is a standard result. And its called}\\ \text{the Product Rule. Review if you got this wrong.}

step.tex: \begin{align} \dfrac{d}{dx}\cos x^3 &= \dfrac{d}{d x^3}\cos x^3\cdot\dfrac{d}{dx} x^3 \\ &= -3x^2\cdot\sin x^3 \\ \dfrac{d}{dx}\sin^2 (x^5) &= \dfrac{d}{d x^5}\sin^2 (x^5)\cdot\dfrac{d}{dx}x^5 \\ &= 5x^4\cdot \left[2\sin x^5\cdot\cos x^5 \right] \\ \therefore f'(x)&= \cos x^3\dfrac{d}{dx}\sin^2 (x^5) + \sin^2 (x^5)\dfrac{d}{dx}\cos x^3 \\ &= 10x^4\sin x^5\cos x^5\cos x^3 -3x^2 \sin x^3 \sin^2 (x^5) \end{align}
step.reason: \text{Don't forget to differentiate the }x^3\text{ in }\cos x^3\\ \text{and the }x^5\text{ in }\sin^2 (x^5).
